author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text: Lost Bible returned to slain USAAF airman from World War II [Saleen Martin](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7245115001/saleen-martin/) During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle. The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription ‚ÄúMay this keep you safe from harm." Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France. His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back. Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarch‚Äôs belongings. On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war. ‚ÄòI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages‚Äô Coogan‚Äôs uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.‚Äù Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums. ‚ÄúThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,‚Äù Coogan told USA TODAY. ‚ÄúThey would put it in their coat pockets ‚Ä¶ like the front breast pocket ‚Ä¶ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.‚Äù Lt. McKnight‚Äôs name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldn‚Äôt put it down, she recalled. ‚ÄúI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,‚Äù she said. She noticed that the Bible‚Äôs front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out. Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bible‚Äôs cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bible‚Äôs safe return to an address not too far away. Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called. ‚ÄúI was just hoping for the best,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúWe found out that number worked.‚Äù Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York. Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Force‚Äôs 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, [online records](https://rafbeaulieu.co.uk/honouring-the-airmen-of-raf-beaulieu/) show. Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fay‚Äôs husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life. ‚ÄúHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,‚Äù Coogan said. Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost. ‚ÄúHe didn't lose it,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale ‚Ä¶ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.‚Äù It ended up in Coogan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said. ‚ÄúThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,‚Äù she said.

author: admin
title: Plumbing Supply Firm Loses Appeal Over Sales Reps‚Äô Overtime Pay
text: A federal appeals court has upheld a district court ruling that a wholesale distributor of plumbing supplies has wrongly exempted its inside sales representatives from overtime pay for years. The 1st Circuit Court of Appeals denied F.W. Webb‚Äôs request for a new hearing. As a result, the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) which sued the firm in 2020, will recover $4.2 million in overtime back wages from the plumbing supply firm for more than 700 inside sales representatives of the company. The department alleged that Webb violated the Fair Labor Standards Act by treating its inside sales representatives (ISRs) as exempt administrative employees and failing to pay them overtime premiums for their hours worked over 40 hours in a workweek. The department also alleged the employer failed to keep adequate and accurate records of hours worked. DOL argued that the ISRs are ineligible for the administrative exemption because their primary duty is to produce sales, Webb‚Äôs principal business is producing sales, and the ISRs are not predominately engaged in administrative work. Webb argued that the ISRs are covered under the administrative exemption because their primary duty is providing solutions to Webb‚Äôs customers and that they help develop strategy, and enjoy broad discretion and authority on matters of significance as part of their role. In June 2023, the district court granted summary judgment in favor of DOL on the exemption issue, as well as the overtime and recordkeeping claims. The district court concluded that the ISRs were not administratively exempt because they perform the very work that is F. W. Webb Co.‚Äôs primary business purpose, namely producing wholesale sales. The district court also found that the company had failed to pay the affected workers overtime back wages since August 2018 and violated recordkeeping provisions of the FLSA. In August 2023, the district court entered a consent judgment and stay order that preserved Webb‚Äôs right to appeal the district court‚Äôs summary judgment decision on the administrative exemption and resolved all other outstanding issues in the case. Webb appealed the summary judgment decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 1st Circuit in September 2023. On Aug. 1, 2024, the 1st Circuit affirmed the district court‚Äôs summary judgment decision, agreeing that Webb‚Äôs ISRs are not exempt administrative employees under the FLSA. The 1st Circuit said the affected employees‚Äô ‚Äúprimary duties are not ‚Äòadministrative‚Äô in any sense of the word.‚Äù Webb then petitioned the 1st Circuit to rehear the case en banc, which the 1st Circuit denied on Sept. 4, 2024. According to DOL, Webb has deposited approximately $4.2 million in back wages with the district court that DOL will distribute to the more than 700 employees in the event that Webb does not seek any further appellate review. Based in Bedford, Massachusetts, F.W. Webb Co. sells HVAC and plumbing and heating supplies, bathroom fixtures, pipe valves and fittings, and related equipment to contractors, industry professionals and homeowners. It has wholesale establishments in Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Vermont. Was this article valuable? Here are more articles you may enjoy.

author: Michele Kettner
title: Warm Up with a Hot Bowl of Chili at These NoVA Restaurants
text:
Baby, it‚Äôs cold outside! And when the winter temps get this chilly, you probably start craving comfort food. If you have a hankering for chili, we know where to go. Here‚Äôs where you can find a hot bowl of chili across Northern Virginia.
Bar-J Chili Parlor
Craving Tex-Mex‚Äìstyle chili? Grab a table at this Occoquan establishment. In business for over 40 years, this eatery has five different chili options, including its award-winning Texas chili, which is made with ground beef simmered in Bar J‚Äôs signature hot spices, and Cincinnati chili, made with mild spices. 125 Mill St., Occoquan
Odd BBQ
You‚Äôll come for the barbecue and Ono Brewing beer, but stay for the beef chili. Guests can order a plain bowl or combine it with rice, mac and cheese, or a cheese biscuit. Bowls are topped with shredded cheddar and onions by request. 4520 Daly Dr., Chantilly
Old Dominion Tavern
While beef-based chili is great, but you don‚Äôt want to miss this venison chili. A hot bowl comes with ground venison, beans, sour cream, cheddar cheese, and green onion. 5351 Merchants View Sq., Haymarket
The Ashburn Pub
The award-winning Pub Chili, which is made using the 2014 Loudoun County Chili Cook-off winning recipe, is a favorite in the region. If you‚Äôre looking for a little more substance, order the Chili Mac. The dish combines the Pub Chili with macaroni noodles and is topped with shredded cheese, onions, and tomatoes. Diners can also add pub chili to any entr√©e for $4. 44110 Ashburn Village Blvd., Ashburn
Vienna Inn
For over 60 years, the Vienna Inn has been known for its mouth-watering chili dishes. Options for a bowl include chili with red beans, vegetarian chili, and chili-mac. Chili lovers can also grab a chili or chili-cheese dog, chili cheeseburger, or chili-cheese fries. 120 E. Maple Ave., Vienna
Feature image courtesy Olde Dominion Tavern
For more stories like this,
subscribe to Northern Virginia Magazine‚Äôs Food & Drink newsletter.

author: , Canton Repository
title: OHSAA expands postseason tournaments for high school track and field, cross country
text:
OHSAA expands postseason tournaments for high school track and field, cross country
High school runners, jumpers, throwers and vaulters can rejoice.
The Ohio High School Athletic Association announced Thursday that postseason tournament divisions in track and field and cross country will be expanded beginning with the 2025-26 school year. The move was unanimously approved by the OHSAA's board of directors.
Track and field will add two divisions, increasing from three to five. Cross country will expand from three to four divisions.
Division I tournaments for both sports will have the smallest amount of schools. The number of schools in the other divisions will be divided as equally as possible.
In the current three-division format, the number of schools in each division are divided equally.
The Ohio Association of Track and Cross Country Coaches have made a number of proposals for expansion in both sports. Thursday's decision follows the OHSAA's recent tournament expansion of basketball, baseball, soccer, softball and girls volleyball.
‚ÄúWe have been studying expansion in track and field and cross country for quite some time, just like how we studied expanding divisions in those teams sports,‚Äù OHSAA Executive Director Doug Ute said in a statement. ‚ÄúAdding divisions and decreasing the size of Division I has already brought such a positive change for those team sports, and now we have worked through the process to do that in track and field and cross country. We appreciate the dialogue with the OATCCC leadership and their assistance and patience.‚Äù
Details and postseason format information for track and field and cross country will be announced after the OHSAA board of directors approves the tournament regulations.
Reach Mike at mike.popovich@cantonrep.com
On X: @mpopovichREP

author: John Monta√±o
title: Gracias a hombres y caninos de la Armada Nacional, Montes de Mar√≠a ya es un territorio libre de minas antipersonal
text: Este logro representa un hito significativo para una regi√≥n donde marcharon los ej√©rcitos de la muerte: donde guerrilla y paramilitares, en alianza con la Fuerza P√∫blica, dejaron m√°s de medio centenar de mascares a campesinos inocentes, y envenenaron las tierras f√©rtiles con minas antipersona, donde han ca√≠do guerreros e inocentes por igual, entre ellos muchos ni√±os.Hoy, este anuncio de la Armada Nacional abre nuevas puertas a la paz, la esperanza y el desarrollo sostenible.Los habitantes de Montes de Mar√≠a pueden celebrar la recuperaci√≥n de 770.670 metros cuadrados libres de sospecha de minas y 569.054 metros cuadrados de territorio completamente despejados, informa la Armada Nacional.(Tambi√©n: Cartagena le pone la lupa a $ 14 billones que vale el Plan de Desarrollo 2024- 2027 y exige que se vean las obras)Este avance ha permitido el retorno seguro de pobladores y campesinos a sus lugares de origen, donde ahora cultivan con confianza en los f√©rtiles terrenos, impulsando as√≠ la econom√≠a local. La entrega oficial de esta subregi√≥n montemariana ha sido posible gracias al arduo trabajo del Batall√≥n de Desminado e Ingenieros Anfibios de la Armada de Colombia. Durante a√±os, este batall√≥n ha llevado a cabo labores de desminado en los municipios de Cartagena, C√≥rdoba, El Carmen de Bol√≠var, El Guamo, Mar√≠a la Baja, San Jacinto, San Juan de Nepomuceno, Santa Rosa de Lima, Villanueva y Zambrano en Bol√≠var; as√≠ como en Colos√≥, Corozal, Chal√°n, Galeras, Los Palmitos, Ovejas, Morroa, San Onofre y Sincelejo en Sucre.(Vale la pena leer: Cartagena: Juez ordena que sea devuelto apartamento que habr√≠a sido invadido a extranjero, por un vecino, en el Centro Hist√≥rico)"El Carmen de Bol√≠var es el √∫ltimo municipio intervenido con la atenci√≥n de 533 eventos sospechosos, 296 estudios no t√©cnicos, 69 √°reas peligrosas intervenidas, 108 artefactos destruidos, 1.264 personas capacidades en riesgo de minas y 378.575 metros cuadrados de √°rea despejada", se√±ala la Armada Nacional.Estas acciones se enmarcan en los compromisos adquiridos por Colombia en la firma del Tratado de Ottawa, que proh√≠be el empleo, almacenamiento, producci√≥n y transferencia de Minas Antipersonal. La Instancia Interinstitucional de Desminado Humanitario, conformada por el Ministerio de Defensa Nacional, la Oficina del Consejero Comisionado de Paz y la Inspecci√≥n General de las Fuerzas Militares, asign√≥ a la Compa√±√≠a de Desminado Humanitario de la Armada de Colombia la tarea de erradicar la sospecha de contaminaci√≥n por minas antipersonal en 19 municipios de la Subregi√≥n de los Montes de Mar√≠a.Durante este proceso, estos hombres y caninos realizaron investigaciones exhaustivas para identificar √°reas contaminadas, y se llevaron a cabo intervenciones para neutralizar las amenazas encontradas.(Adem√°s: Este es el plan en Cartagena para combatir la violencia e inseguridad: analistas hablan)Un total de 2.250 Infantes de Marina del Batall√≥n de Desminado e Ingenieros Anfibios participaron en estas operaciones, investigando 1.066 eventos sospechosos y neutralizando 251 amenazas, incluyendo minas antipersonales, munici√≥n sin explosionar y artefactos explosivos improvisados. Adem√°s del desminado, la Armada de Colombia llev√≥ a cabo actividades de sensibilizaci√≥n en riesgo de minas antipersonal, capacitando a m√°s de 5.695 habitantes de la regi√≥n para identificar y reportar este tipo de artefactos explosivos.Estas iniciativas fueron monitoreadas por el programa de Acci√≥n Integral contra Minas Antipersonal de la Organizaci√≥n de los Estados Americanos, que certific√≥ el cumplimiento de los est√°ndares nacionales de desminado humanitario.El anuncio oficial de la liberaci√≥n de Montes de Mar√≠a de minas antipersonal tuvo lugar en un acto simb√≥lico en El Carmen de Bol√≠var, presidido por el Presidente de la Rep√∫blica, Gustavo Petro, y acompa√±ado por el Consejero Comisionado de Paz, Otty Pati√±o; el Ministro de Defensa, Iv√°n Vel√°squez; la c√∫pula militar, autoridades locales y regionales, as√≠ como l√≠deres de la comunidad. Este hito marca un paso importante hacia la consolidaci√≥n de la paz y el desarrollo en la regi√≥n del Caribe colombiano. La Armada de Colombia continuar√° trabajando para mantener las condiciones de seguridad en la zona, y hace un llamado a la comunidad a seguir apoyando las iniciativas de integraci√≥n y desarrollo regional.El desminado de Montes de Mar√≠a es un ejemplo de c√≥mo la cooperaci√≥n y el compromiso pueden transformar una regi√≥n afectada por el conflicto en un entorno seguro y pr√≥spero para sus habitantes. Cartagena‚Äã*Con informaci√≥n de la Armada Nacional

author: Anthony Robledo
title: Viral photo of forlorn Spiral Hot Dogs owner leads to booming business
text: Customer's photo of forlorn owner in empty restaurant leads business to boom at OK diner Nick Chappell had never been to Spirals Hot Dogs & More before he took a photo of Scott Hosek in his empty restaurant. But after business boomed, Chappell's part of the Spirals family, Hosek says. [Anthony Robledo](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7612431001/anthony-robledo/) An Oklahoma hot dog joint owner visibly wanted customers one day and he soon got more than he bargained for. During a slow shift on Dec. 20, a customer took a photo of Scott Hosek standing by his restaurant entrance waiting for diners and shared it on social media. Hosek would soon have no time to stand around as " [Spirals: Hot Dogs & More](https://spiralshotdogs.com/)," in Norman, Oklahoma, saw booming business once the post went viral. "We immediately started doing double digits in sales," Hosek told USA TODAY on Thursday. "It happened really fast to me." The day the photo was taken, Hosek found himself staring out the window upset his family business of four years wasn't booming as well as others ahead of Christmas. Hosek said he had no idea why Spirals saw a sudden wave of new customers after Dec. 20 until the person responsible for posting the photo, Nick Chappell, later apologized and offered to take the post down. Hosek wouldn't hear of it. "You just wouldn't expect it. Social media is amazing. It's amazing that people get involved with it," he said. "But more importantly, it's the stuff that you just don't think would work. That's what works." 'I will always love you': [See Dolly Parton grant Utah man's dying wish to meet her](/story/life/humankind/2023/12/26/dolly-parton-meets-longtime-fan/72033945007/) Customer knew he had to capture 'wholesome moment' Chappell visited the Norman area for his job as an Oklahoma Army National Guard. As part of their weekly hot dog Wednesday routine, Chappell and a his co-worker found Spirals on Google Maps and took a chance. Noticing Hosek gazing, Chappell decided to capture the "wholesome moment" on Snapchat captioning "He has been standing here waiting on customers to come in." "A good buddy of mine named Chad said, 'Hey, man, you can either post this on Facebook or I'm going to post this on Facebook. Some way or another we're going to get this guy some customers,'" Chappell said. In a Facebook post, Chappell gave an excellent recommendation of the restaurant, complimenting their food and "off the charts" service. He shared a photo of his dish, the menu and of Hosek waiting for diners. Chappell was blown away by the success of the post, which has since had over 2,000 shares, and even more surprised to see over 70 guests at the diner during his next visit. "I'm not a huge social media guy I typically don't share," Chappell said. "I don't even know really the words to describe it as but it made me even that much happier that I did make a post." Owner adds new 'Thunderbird' item in customer's honor Hosek is showing his gratitude by adding a new item in Chappell's honor. Having named hot dogs and bowls after family members, he was more than happy to do so. The "Thunderbird" is a hot link with bacon, cream cheese and jalape√±os, Hosek said. The meal gets its name from the Thunderbird Unit Patch for the 45th Infantry, which Chappell is a part of. The two reconnected at the restaurant on Thursday, where they both got emotional talking about the post's impact. Chappell received a certificate of appreciation during the unveiling of the "Thunderbird" and was told he is now forever part of the Spirals family. "To know that it was a humble guy that just saw our need and did what he could. He doesn‚Äôt have a real following on social media, he hardly ever shares anything and to know that one post had so much power. It was super cool," Hosek added.

author: jdhorux
title: #148 La queja de los turistas brit√°nicos sobre Benidorm: "demasiados espa√±oles"
text:
[alesay](/user/alesay)a [viajar.elperiodico.com](/go/link/3953499) [#5](c5#c-5) A√±adir√© un dato curioso o√≠do de boca de un grupo de guiris (y de otros), algunos piensan que la gente no vive en la ciudad que pisa y que la gente vive en otros lugares creyendo realmente que es una especie de parque de atracciones pintoresco.
O√≠do en Madrid+pueblos de la comunidad, Valencia y Alicante. En sevilla lo que o√≠ fue lo de siempre de que qu√© raro, la gente viste normal.
[#43](c43#c-43) Puedes pasarte unos links?
Mi familia tiene un apartamento, y siempre que voy lo que peor llevo es el tema restaurantes. No se si es mala suerte, pero no encuentro termino medio: o es car√≠simo o es mal√≠simo. A veces ambos.
Es una pena, sobretodo cuando vienen amigos y no se a donde llevarles üò∞
[#119](c119#c-119) te recomiendo que, adem√°s de moverte por Benidorm, vayas a Villajoyosa y Altea. Hay restaurantes de mucha calidad. Si quieres algo m√°s concreto por Benidorm te puedo decir.
Lo primero que hay que entender sobre Benidorm es que hay diferentes zonas y si bien est√° lo que los lugare√±os llamamos "la zona guiri", hay muchas otras zonas donde apenas hay extranjeros y es mayor√≠a de turismo nacional o gente del pueblo.
